abstract.p: This article reports on proof-of-concept experimental work carried out to demonstrate a wideband vibro-impacting energy harvesting approach based on a magnet/bearing arrangement coupled with a magnetoelectric transducer. The harvesting arrangement uses a Terfenol-D/Pz27 laminate transducer (disc with radius 5 mm) positioned between an oscillating spherical chrome-steel bearing and a rare earth magnet. The oscillating bearing steers magnetic field through the magnetoelectric transducer, generating an oscillating charge that can be harvested. A vibro-impacting arrangement between the oscillating bearing (radius 12.7 mm) and a pair of aluminium mechanical stops is designed to produce a wideband frequency response. For a 434 mG host acceleration, the vibro-impact mechanism produced a bandwidth of ∼7.2 Hz (between 6 and ∼13.2 Hz). The issue of damage to the mechanical stops caused by the vibro-impacting process is also explored and was demonstrated experimentally and theoretically to be inconsequential. This non-optimized wideband harvesting approach has demonstrated a generated power of 3.3 µW from a root mean square host acceleration of 180 m-g at 8.0 Hz.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Australian Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) is developing a variety of in situ structural health monitoring (SHM) approaches, for example, Galea et al. (2009) and Galea and Powlesland (2009), for potential use in high-value platforms across the Australian Defence Force (ADF). The SHM systems under development for air vehicles could be employed to (a) continuously monitor airframe loads and accelerations during flight, (b) detect damage and damage growth and other structural problems and (c) provide a basis for near real-time damage assessment. More generally, the implementation of SHM systems would allow the ADF to move from expensive interval-based inspection and maintenance regimes for ageing platforms to more cost-effective condition-based approaches, and therefore reduce aircraft through-life support costs. In 2004, US$59 billion in maintenance costs made up 14% of the US Department of Defence (DoD) budget (Adams, 2007). To help manage these large maintenance costs, the US DoD has adopted a policy requiring its military departments to use condition-based maintenance approaches where suitable (Morales, 2002).

Although SHM technology could potentially permit a safe reduction in maintenance costs with a concomitant increase in inspection intervals, the certification of SHM systems for use on aircraft raises a number of challenges. One critical issue is determining the optimal means of supplying power to these systems. It is expected that the majority of SHM devices would need to be fitted on internal aircraft structure, underneath the aircraft’s skin. If an SHM device is in a location that is difficult to access, then powering the device can be problematic because replacing batteries on numerous SHM devices deployed across a fleet would be impractical, and accessing existing on-board power to supply SHM devices may lead to flight worthiness and certification issues.

Powering of SHM systems is thus a critical issue. DSTO has previously shown that a structural strain–based energy-harvesting approach can be used to power a device for SHM of aircraft structure (Galea et al., 2009). Energy harvesting itself is normally thought of as being the process of capturing ambient waste energy from the local environment and converting it into electrical form, typically for the purpose of powering sensor and wireless communications systems (Beeby and White, 2010; Priya and Inman, 2009). In the context of powering SHM systems on aircraft, vibration energy harvesting involves capturing waste mechanical energy from structural vibrations (including strain and acceleration) and then converting it into a usable electrical form (Anton and Inman, 2011). In general, the narrow bandwidth, uniaxial nature and relatively large mass of most current commercial vibration energy harvesting devices have limited their progression, particularly in the air vehicle domain (Moss et al., 2010a). Recently, DSTO has investigated acceleration-based vibration energy harvesting for use on airframes and has explored harvesting strategies with the specific aims of achieving a wider operational frequency bandwidth (Moss et al., 2011) combined with a multiaxial response (Moss 2011; Moss et al., 2012).

A fundamental issue with many vibration energy–harvesting approaches is that they have a relatively narrowband frequency response. DSTO (Moss et al., 2010b, 2010c) and others (Blystad and Halvorsen, 2011; Jacquelin et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2011; Mak et al., 2010) have explored the possibility of using the physical process of vibro-impact (Babitsky, 1998) as a mechanism to facilitate broadband vibration energy harvesting. The vibro-impact energy harvesting approach uses a machine chatter–type (Babitsky, 1998) process to achieve a wider frequency of operation relative to a single-degree-of-freedom harvester (Adhikari et al., 2009). The benefit of using the vibro-impact mechanism for energy harvesting is that it is naturally a broadband phenomenon. The authors believe that the vibro-impact mechanism may be exploited for auto-tuning a vibration energy harvester in a frequency-rich mechanical environment, such as an aircraft in flight.

Another fundamental issue with many vibration energy harvesting approaches is that they are unidirectional, and hence can only efficiently harvest vibrational energy from host accelerations along a single axis. Therefore, while a considerable amount of scientific literature exists on the topic of vibration energy harvesting (Kazmierski and Beeby, 2011; Roundy et al., 2004), none to date has been able to effectively harvest from biaxial host accelerations. Previous work by DSTO (Moss et al., 2012) has described a biaxial approach for vibration energy harvesting. Specifically, the approach increases the potential operational directionality from single axis to 360° in a plane. The approach uses a magnet/ball-bearing arrangement, replacing the cantilever design used by many harvesters described in the literature. Host vibrations cause the ball bearing to oscillate, which in turn causes magnetic flux to steer through a magnetoelectric (ME) laminate transducer to generate harvestable electrical power. A potential benefit of the magnet/ball-bearing arrangement is that it allows a reduction in harvester volume and mass.

This article describes proof-of-concept experimental work undertaken towards combining the DSTO wideband vibro-impacting approach with a transducer design potentially capable of multiaxial energy harvesting in a single compact and robust device.

sec.title: Principles of operation
sec.p: The harvesting approach discussed in this article uses a ME transduction mechanism that has been described elsewhere (see Moss et al., 2012). In summary, referring to Figure 1(a), as the bearing oscillates in the x–y plane (where x is normal to the page) the magnetic field distribution in the ME transducer changes. Figure 1(b) shows the predicted magnetic field for the bearing in a centred position (‘Central Ball’) and displaced from that position (‘Offset Ball’). Figure 1(c) describes the expected magnetostrictive deformation as the bearing position is changed, with the top Terfenol-D element contracting (y-direction) when the bearing is centred and expanding when the bearing is displaced. The magnetostrictive deformations apply a time-varying three-dimensional bulk stress to the piezoelectric layer producing a sinusoidal piezoelectric charge, which in turn generates a voltage across the attached load resistor. Note that based on the results of previous model predictions (McLeod et al., 2012; Moss et al., 2012), the authors believe that compressive stresses acting on the piezoelectric element in the z-direction (due to the squeezing action of the bearing and magnet) do not make a substantial contribution to the charge generated. As shown in Figure 1(a), the central line of the harvester is defined as the vertical line (z-direction) through the centre of the magnet. The bearing travels between two vertical mechanical stops (made from aluminium alloy). If the amplitude of displacement of the bearing is nominally greater than the stop-gap distance Δ (as shown in Figure 1(a)), the bearing will undergo an impact collision with a mechanical stop and may enter a mechanical behaviour known as vibro-impact (Babitsky, 1998), hence producing a relatively wideband frequency response.

caption.p: (a) Two-dimensional schematic of the wideband vibration energy harvester examined in this work. Host vibration is along the y axis. The ME transducer is located between the bearing and magnets. ‘Central Ball’ indicates the rest position, and Fymagnet is the magnetic restoring force on the displaced bearing, or ‘Offset Ball’. If the bearing’s displacement is sufficiently large it will collide with a mechanical stop (with aluminium spacer between ball and steel host structure not shown). (b) Schematics showing predicted magnetic stream lines for the bearing centrally located and the bearing having an offset (in the y-direction) from the z-axis central-line of the ME transducer. (c) The expected magnetostrictive response as the bearing changes position. (Not to scale.)
ME: magnetoelectric; PZT: lead zirconate titanate.

sec.title: Experimental
sec.p: Figure 1(a) shows a schematic of the permanent-magnet/ball-bearing oscillator arrangement used by the harvester, including the relative location of the ME transducer. The chrome-steel ball-bearing (grade AISI 52100) has a radius of 12.7 mm. The bearing rolls on a 0.8 mm thick, 15 mm radius tungsten carbide (6% cobalt by mass) wear pad that is used to protect the upper surface of the ME transducer. The rare earth magnets (NdFeB, grade N42) and the ME transducer are cylindrical and have a radius of 5 mm. The ME transducer was formed by bonding the Terfenol-D (Etrema Products) and lead zirconate titanate elements (Ferroperm Piezoceramics Pz27) with silver-loaded epoxy (Circuitworks CW2400) that was cured for 2 h at 65°C. In order to maximize output from the ME transducer, the magnetostrictive and piezoelectric layers were made 1.5 and 0.5 mm thick, respectively, as described in the study by Ryu et al. (2001). The magnets, and the piezoceramic 3-direction (Berlincourt et al., 1964), are poled in the z-direction. The magnets are 10 mm thick, and for convenience, two magnets were stacked together and magnetically attached to a 5 mm thick steel base.

Figure 2 depicts the experimental arrangement, showing the harvester attached to a 5 kg host mass, connected to a 75 N vibration shaker. As shown in Figure 2(a), mechanical stops were created by bolting three aluminium spacers (each 3 mm thick for total 9 mm) to each side of a steel housing with wall thickness 10 mm. During an impact event, the bearing collides with an aluminium surface, with the mechanical impulse load then transferred into the steel housing. The total inner distance between the two mechanical stops was 32.5 mm. Given that the bearing radius was 12.7 mm, the stop-gap distance is calculated as Δ∼ (32.5−2 × 12.7 mm)/2=3.5 mm. Note that the open-circuit voltage and power measurements presented in this article were obtained from the uniaxial harvester arrangement shown in Figures 1(a) and 2(a).

caption.p: (a) Experimental arrangement, and measurements of the harvester’s (b) open-circuit voltage, and (c) power and voltage as a function of load resistance R.

sec.p: An accelerometer mounted on the 5 kg host mass was used to set the desired root mean square (rms) host acceleration, at host frequency 7.5 Hz, prior to sweeping the frequency. Frequencies from 6 to 14 Hz were swept in 0.1 Hz steps. Host frequencies below 6 Hz were not examined due to frequency limitations of the vibration shaker. Host acceleration variation was within ±10 mG during a sweep (where 1 G = 9.8 m/s2). Dwell time at each frequency was 10 s, after which time the next frequency step was immediately applied (with care taken to ensure a smooth transition between frequency steps). Voltage and power measurements were made using the circuit arrangements shown in Figure 2(b) and (c). The measurement sampling rate was 12 kSPS. The measured capacitance of the ME transducer was 1.86 nF, suggesting an impedance at 8 Hz of XC = 1/(2 πf C) ∼ 10.7 MΩ. This impedance is larger than the 8 MΩ input impedance of the differential probe (Hameg HZ109), hence a large resistance (90 MΩ) was added in series with the probe to ensure that the transducer voltages were measured accurately.

sec.title: Theory
sec.p: This section will describe the modelling of the harvester that was undertaken to understand the magnetic restoring force acting between the bearing and the magnet and also the mechanical spring constants that act during an impact between the bearing and the housing. The possibility of vibro-impact-induced damage on the mechanical stops is also examined.

The bearing shown in Figure 1(a) is subject to a magnetic restoring force in the x–y plane, but is otherwise free to move across the surface of the upper magnetostrictive element in response to host structure oscillations.

COMSOL AB (2008) Multiphysics software was used to make predictions about the restoring force Fy (rotational effects were ignored). A three-dimensional model was developed using the COMSOL application mode ‘magnetostatics, no currents’, taking into account the cylindrical nature of the magnets and the spherical bearing, and solving for the Maxwell stress tensor.

Magnetic force predictions were made assuming that the ME transducer acted as a 4.4 mm air gap between the magnet and the bearing. A concern when adopting the vibro-impact approach for energy harvesting is the deleterious effect that the impact process may have on the materials involved. For example, if the working velocity of a material is exceeded, then plastic deformation could result. The working velocity, v*, is approximated in the literature (Babitsky, 1998) as,

where G is a material’s shear modulus and ρ is its density. Babitsky (1998) assumes an elastic limit for steel ε* = 0.001, the authors assume the same limit for the aluminium alloy used as mechanical stops. Table 1 shows that the estimated working velocity for aluminium and steel is similar and around 3 m/s. The working velocity for both of these materials should not exceed this critical value.

caption.p: Material properties for aluminium and steel.

sec.p: It should be noted that the impact velocity required for the initial yield of metals can be significantly smaller than the working velocities shown in Table 1. For example, equations given by Stronge (2004) predict that an impact velocity of 0.01 m/s is sufficient for a steel bearing (with radius 12.7 mm) to produce plastic deformation on the surface of an aluminium plate, because during impact, the contact stress is greater than the yield strength Y of aluminium alloy (see Table 1 and Appendix 1). If the impact velocity is increased to 0.35 m/s, then Stronge’s equations predict that the contact area between the bearing and the aluminium stop will have a contact radius of ∼0.46 mm (see Appendix 1). Assuming that the initial contact radius is ∼0.46 mm, the initial contact stress is calculated to be ∼1380 MPa (see Appendix 1), which is well above the yield strength for aluminium shown in Table 1. The authors believe that after an initial ‘wear in’ period, the impacts between the bearing and mechanical stops would become more spherically conformal due to local deformation of the aluminium. Such a process would result in increased contact area and hence reduced contact pressure during subsequent impact events, and so reduce the rate of collision-induced damage suffered by the mechanical stops.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: In this section, the measured open-circuit voltage and output power of the harvester are explored as a function of frequency, host acceleration and load resistance. A detailed examination of the open-circuit voltage is carried out to elucidate the dynamics of the impact process. A numerical model is developed to explore the harvester’s vibro-impacting behaviour. Finally, the issue of vibro-impact induced damage to the mechanical stops is examined.

Figure 4 shows measured open-circuit harvesting voltage as a function of host acceleration and frequency (the experimental arrangement is depicted in Figure 2(b)). The data presented in Figure 4 have been low-pass filtered with a cut-off frequency of 25 Hz. For the smallest host acceleration used, 27 m-g, there was little or no interaction between the harvester’s oscillating bearing and the mechanical stops (i.e. no vibro-impact), and hence, the half-power frequency bandwidth is a relatively narrow∼0.23 Hz and is centred at 7.5 Hz. The narrowband response is discussed in more detail later in this article (see Figure 7). The measured central frequency of 7.5 Hz is marginally lower than the resonant frequency of 8.1 Hz calculated in the previous section, presumably because of the softening spring effect (indicated in Figure 3). As the host acceleration is increased, a vibro-impact process between the bearing and the aluminium stops occurs, producing an increase in the harvester’s operational frequency bandwidth (similar to the bandwidth widening mechanism previously reported in the study by Moss et al., 2010a, 2012). The largest host acceleration used, 434 m-g, produced the largest bandwidth, ∼7.2 Hz, approximately 31 times greater than the bandwidth observed using a 27 m-g host acceleration. As demonstrated previously (Moss, 2010a), for the harvesting arrangement investigated in this article, it is expected that the bandwidth of power measurements (made using an optimized electrical load) will exhibit a similar wideband characteristic to that seen in the measured open-circuit voltage. Note that the relatively large measured open-circuit voltage off resonance (∼1.7 V) shown in Figure 4 was due to the combined effect of non-resonant bearing motion and residual electrical noise.

caption.p: Measured open-circuit voltage as a function of RMS host acceleration and frequency.

sec.p: The output power of the harvesting arrangement was measured using the setup depicted in Figure 2(c). A constant rms host acceleration of 180 m-g at 8 Hz was chosen, and the load resistance R was swept from 1 to 11 MΩ. This range of load resistances includes the 10.7 MΩ transducer impedance calculated in the ‘Experimental’ section. The measured optimum electrical load was 5.1 MΩ, which produced an rms load voltage of 4.1 V and hence a load power of ∼3.3 µW. As reported elsewhere (Moss et al., 2010a), an estimate of the limit of mechanical power for a vibro-impacting energy harvester can be made using the equation,

where a is the peak host acceleration (m/s2), f is the host frequency (Hz) and l is the free length of travel (m) of the seismic mass m (kg). For the harvester described in this article, for an rms host acceleration of 180 m-g at 8 Hz, and with a total travel of l∼ 7 mm, equation (7) estimates a limit of power P∼ 17.2 mW. This is substantially greater than the measured harvester output power shown in Figure 5 and indicates that the harvesting arrangement shown in Figure 1(a) is non-optimized. In particular, the authors believe that optimizing the magnetic arrangement of the ME transducer will produce a substantial increase in harvested power.

caption.p: Measured harvester voltage and power as a function of load resistance, R.

sec.p: A detailed examination of the measured open-circuit harvester voltage was done to deduce information regarding the impact process, with typical results shown in Figure 6. Note that the data presented in Figure 6 have been notch-filtered to remove mains noise, which occurs at 50 Hz in Australia. For the particular applied host frequency and acceleration (8 Hz, 104 m-g), the impacts appear on the voltage trace in Figure 6(a) as high frequency spikes (that ring-down) and occur every two voltage cycles. Note that the 8 Hz mechanical resonance of the bearing is frequency doubled to 16 Hz (Figure 6(a)) in the open-circuit voltage traces. This frequency doubling occurs because for each mechanical half-cycle, the bearing traverses from one edge of the transducer (maximum voltage), across the middle of the face of the transducer (minimum voltage), to the other transducer edge (back to maximum voltage). The high frequency response (Figure 6(b)) after impact is not frequency doubled since the bearing does not pass across the middle face of the transducer during an impact (oscillating about the point of contact with the mechanical stop). The frequency-doubling effect will halve the previously calculated impedance of the ME transducer, that is, reducing the impedance from 10.7 to 5.4 MΩ, which is similar to the measured optimum load resistance of 5.1 MΩ (as shown in Figure 5).

caption.p: (a) Measured open-circuit voltage to determine the impact duration, (b) enhanced view of open-circuit voltage just after impact, and (c) amplitude spectrum of the measured open-circuit voltage.

sec.p: The voltage trace can be used to estimate the duration of the impact of the bearing on one of the aluminium mechanical stops. The period of the impact trace shown in Figure 6(b), starting at ∼0.163 s, is ∼640 µs suggesting an impact frequency of 1560 Hz. The impact frequency can also be estimated using the previously calculated (see ‘Theory’ section) effective spring constant of the impact process, that is,

The calculated impact frequency correlates reasonably well with the measured impact frequency given above (1560 Hz) and also with the amplitude spectrum of the measured open-circuit voltage shown in Figure 6(c). An interesting possibility is that the high mechanical frequencies produced by vibro-impact collisions could be used for frequency up-conversion of the energy harvesting process (see, e.g. Gu and Livermore, 2011).

As previously mentioned, for a small host acceleration, there was little or no interaction between the bearing and the mechanical stops. The measured open-circuit voltage shown in Figure 7 (for a 27 m-g host acceleration) can be considered to be (approximately) the linear response of the harvesting arrangement with minimal vibro-impact. The arrangement produced an open-circuit voltage of 6.5 V at a frequency of fR = 7.48 Hz and with a half-power bandwidth of Δf∼ 0.23 Hz. (Note that the peak shown in Figure 7 is cropped due to the 0.1 Hz step size, hence the Δf given is conservative). Making the assumption that the harvesting system is approximately linear when driven by a 27 m-g host acceleration, the estimated mechanical quality of the magnet/bearing arrangement is hence Q = fR/Δf∼ 33.

caption.p: Dymola model to examine the dynamics of the vibro-impacting bearing/magnet system.

sec.p: The model was run at two host frequencies, 8.1 Hz (i.e. natural resonance of the bearing/magnet) and at 13.0 Hz near the existence edge (Babitsky, 1998) of vibro-impact for this system. It is also assumed that the rms host acceleration was constant throughout the simulation interval at 434 m-g, which was the largest host acceleration used experimentally.

Predictions from the model are shown in Figures 9 and 10. Both figures show steady-state displacement and velocity traces for the last 1 s of a 10 s simulation interval. It should be noted that an 8.1 Hz, 434 m-g rms host acceleration will have a peak displacement of 2.3 mm. Ignoring the small elastic penetration of the bearing into the aluminium mechanical stop during impact, the maximum absolute displacement for the bearing can be found by summing the host displacement and the stop-gap distance Δ = 3.5 mm. Hence, the maximum absolute peak displacement of the bearings shown in Figures 9 and 10 is less than ∼5.8 mm.

caption.p: Predicted absolute displacement (upper) and velocity (lower) of the vibro-impacting bearing/magnet arrangement, at steady-state, for a 434 mG host acceleration at 8.1 Hz.
Predicted absolute displacement (upper) and velocity (lower) of the vibro-impacting bearing/magnet arrangement, at steady-state, for a 434 mG host acceleration at 13.0 Hz.

sec.p: Within the vibro-impacting frequency range of existence (Babitsky, 1998), the harvester’s vibro-impact process is able to ‘auto-tune’ itself to maintain a resonant bearing motion. This ‘auto-tuning’ process produces the significant differences that can be seen when comparing the displacement and velocity traces in Figure 9 (with host oscillating at 8.1 Hz) with those in Figure 10 (with host oscillating at 13.0 Hz). For the two example host frequencies shown, the peak bearing velocities are less than 0.35 m/s.

As proposed in the ‘Theory’ section of this article, an impact velocity of 0.35 m/s suggests that a small amount of plastic deformation at the surface of the aluminium stop may occur during the harvester’s ‘wear in’ period. Because an impact velocity of 0.35 m/s is approximately ten times smaller than the maximum working velocities for steel and aluminium given in Table 1, it is believed that the vibro-impact induced damage in the mechanical stops may be inconsequential over an extended period of harvester usage.

For an impact velocity of 0.35 m/s, the equations by Stronge (2004) predict that the radius of the initial contact area between the bearing and a mechanical stop is 0.46 mm and that the initial contact stress is 1380 MPa and hence well above the yield strength for aluminium (Table 1). Figure 11 shows a photograph of the impact region on one of the aluminium stops after a number of hours of vibro-impact experimentation. The impact region is circular and appears as polished aluminium indicating that some local surface deformation had occurred over the course of many thousands of impacts. If the initial contact radius is ∼0.46 mm as predicted, then Figure 11 shows that after testing, the radius of the impact region had increased to 0.9 mm and is believed to be spherically conformal with the surface profile of the bearing. The contact area during an impact event would hence be ∼3.8 times greater than its initial size, which would reduce the impact stress down to ∼60.1 MPa (see Appendix 1). This value is below the yield strength of the aluminium stop (Table 1). It appears that for the harvesting arrangement examined, the vibro-impact testing carried out to date has induced only minimal damage in the mechanical stops.

caption.p: Photograph of the surface of an aluminium stop showing the impact region after hours of ad-hoc testing (scale marker in mm).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A wideband vibro-impacting energy harvester approach has been developed that uses a magnet/bearing arrangement coupled with an ME transducer. Proof-of-concept experimental work has been carried out to demonstrate the approach. In particular, the experimental harvester arrangement uses a Terfenol-D/Pz27 laminate transducer positioned between an oscillating spherical chrome-steel bearing and a rare earth magnet (NdFeB), with a thin tungsten carbide wear pad to protect the transducer surface from mechanical damage caused by the oscillating bearing. The harvester dynamics are governed by the vibro-impacting mechanism that develops between the bearing and a pair of aluminium mechanical stops, which produces resonant oscillatory bearing motion across a relatively wide range of input frequencies and accelerations. The oscillating bearing steers magnetic field through the transducer, generating an oscillating charge that can be harvested. The vibro-impact harvesting mechanism was observed to increase harvester bandwidth by a factor of 31 for the largest host acceleration investigated (434 m-g). The issue of damage to the mechanical stops caused by the vibro-impacting process has been explored, and to date, stop damage has been inconsequential. This non-optimized wideband harvesting approach is capable of harvesting 3.3 µW from an rms host acceleration of 180 m-g at 8.0 Hz. The approach described in this article produces an effective wideband characteristic that may in the future be useful for vibration energy harvesting in a frequency-rich mechanical loading environment, such as that found on an aircraft in flight.
